title: Quantum Random Access Codes for Boolean Functions

sections.our results:
This paper focuses on generalizing the classical, quantum and entanglement-assisted random access codes. Instead of recovering a single bit from the initial string xâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{-1,1\}^{n}, we are interested in evaluating a Boolean function f:{âˆ’1,1}kâ†’{âˆ’1,1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript11ğ‘˜11f:\{-1,1\}^{k}	o\{-1,1\} on any sequence of kğ‘˜k bits from xğ‘¥x. We generically call them fğ‘“f-random access codes. Alice gets xâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{-1,1\}^{n} and she needs to encode her data and send it to Bob, so that he can decode fâ€‹(xS)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘†f(x_{S}) for any Sâˆˆğ’®nkğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘˜S\in\mathcal{S}_{n}^{k} with probability p>1/2ğ‘12p>1/2. Such problem was already considered by Sherstov in a two-way communication complexity settingÂ  and later used in his pattern matrix methodÂ  in order to prove other communication complexity lower bounds. Even though our results are expressed in a random access code language, they can also be seen as in a one-way communication complexity setting. If two-way communication is allowed, Bob can send the identity of his sequence to Alice with Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n) bits of communication, whereas (as we will see) significantly more communication may be required in the one-way scenario. In the following, Î Î \Pi will refer to a sample space with some probability distribution. As before, PR and SR stand for private and shared randomness, respectively. Moreover, since we require the success probability to always be greater than 1/2121/2, given that one can always guess the correct result with probability 1/2121/2, from now on it will be convenient to use the bias Îµğœ€\varepsilon of the prediction, defined as Îµ=2â€‹pâˆ’1ğœ€2ğ‘1\varepsilon=2p-1, instead of its success probability pğ‘p. An nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-QRAC with SR is an encoding map E:{âˆ’1,1}nÃ—Î â†’â„‚2m:ğ¸â†’superscript11ğ‘›Î superscriptâ„‚superscript2ğ‘šE:\{-1,1\}^{n}	imes\Pi	o\mathbb{C}^{2^{m}} that assigns an mğ‘šm-qubit pure state to every xâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{-1,1\}^{n} and satisfies the following: for every Sâˆˆğ’®nkğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘˜S\in\mathcal{S}_{n}^{k} there is a set of POVMs {MrS}râˆˆÎ subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿğ‘ŸÎ \{M^{S}_{r}\}_{r\in\Pi}, with MrS={Mâˆ’1,rS,M1,rS}subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘†1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘†1ğ‘ŸM^{S}_{r}=\{M^{S}_{-1,r},M^{S}_{1,r}\}, such that ğ”¼râ€‹[Eâ€‹(x,r)â€ â€‹Mfâ€‹(xS),rSâ€‹Eâ€‹(x,r)]â‰¥12+12â€‹Îµsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘Ÿdelimited-[]ğ¸superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿâ€ subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘†ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿğ¸ğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿ1212ğœ€\mathbb{E}_{r}[E(x,r)^{\dagger}M^{S}_{f(x_{S}),r}E(x,r)]\geq rac{1}{2}+ rac{1}{2}\varepsilon for all xâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{-1,1\}^{n}. Similarly, we define nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-EARAC, the fğ‘“f-entanglement-assisted random access code on mğ‘šm bits with bias Îµğœ€\varepsilon. An nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-EARAC is an nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-RAC with SR where the encoding and decoding parties share an unlimited amount of entangled quantum states. Due to shared entanglement being a source of SR, we already include SR in fğ‘“f-EARACs. We note thatÂ  focused on EARACs without SR. Finally, we define nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-PRRAC, the fğ‘“f-Popescu-Rohrlich random access code on mğ‘šm bits with bias Îµğœ€\varepsilon. A Popescu-Rohrlich boxÂ  is a bipartite system shared by two parties with two inputs x,yâˆˆ{0,1}ğ‘¥ğ‘¦01x,y\in\{0,1\} and two outputs a,bâˆˆ{0,1}ğ‘ğ‘01a,b\in\{0,1\} and is defined by the joint probability distribution An nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-PRRAC is an nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-RAC with SR where the encoding and decoding parties share an unlimited amount of Popescu-Rohrlich boxes. In SectionÂ 3 we devise encoding-decoding strategies for all the fğ‘“f-random access codes just defined, thus deriving lower bounds on their biases given the encoding/decoding parameters n,mğ‘›ğ‘šn,m and kğ‘˜k. These fğ‘“f-random access codes are built based on previous ideas fromÂ [ref]5  . The Boolean function f:{âˆ’1,1}kâ†’{âˆ’1,1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript11ğ‘˜11f:\{-1,1\}^{k}	o\{-1,1\} that needs to be evaluated directly influences the final bias and such influence in our results is captured by the single quantity called noise stabilityÂ  5. Informally it is a measure of how resilient to noise a Boolean function is. Given a uniformly random input xâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{-1,1\}^{n}, one might imagine a process that flips each bit of xğ‘¥x independently with some probability 12âˆ’12â€‹q1212ğ‘ rac{1}{2}- rac{1}{2}q, where qâˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ‘11q\in[-1,1], which leads to some final string yâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¦superscript11ğ‘›y\in\{-1,1\}^{n}. The noise stability Stabqâ¡[f]subscriptStabğ‘ğ‘“\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[f] of fğ‘“f with parameter qğ‘q is the correlation between fâ€‹(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x) and fâ€‹(y)ğ‘“ğ‘¦f(y) (see SectionÂ 2 for a formal definition). Our positive results can be summarized by the following theorem. Let f:{âˆ’1,1}kâ†’{âˆ’1,1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript11ğ‘˜11f:\{-1,1\}^{k}	o\{-1,1\} be a Boolean function and Stabqâ¡[f]subscriptStabğ‘ğ‘“\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[f] its noise stability with parameter qğ‘q. Let â„“âˆˆâ„•â„“â„•\ell\in\mathbb{N}. If m=Î©â€‹(â„“â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘šÎ©â„“ğ‘›m=\Omega(\ell\log{n}) and k=oâ€‹(â„“)ğ‘˜ğ‘œâ„“k=o(\sqrt{\ell}), there is an nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-RAC with PR and bias Îµâ‰¥(1âˆ’onâ€‹(1))â€‹Stabqâ¡[f]ğœ€1subscriptğ‘œğ‘›1subscriptStabğ‘ğ‘“\varepsilon\geq(1-o_{n}(1))\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[f] with qâ‰¥mnâˆ’5â€‹log2â¡(n/â„“)n/â„“ğ‘ğ‘šğ‘›5subscript2ğ‘›â„“ğ‘›â„“q\geq\sqrt{ rac{m}{n}- rac{5\log_{2}{(n/\ell)}}{n/\ell}}. If k=oâ€‹(m)ğ‘˜ğ‘œğ‘šk=o(\sqrt{m}), there is an nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-RAC with SR and Îµâ‰¥(1âˆ’onâ€‹(1))â€‹Stabqâ¡[f]ğœ€1subscriptğ‘œğ‘›1subscriptStabğ‘ğ‘“\varepsilon\geq(1-o_{n}(1))\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[f] with qâ‰¥m2â€‹nğ‘ğ‘š2ğ‘›q\geq\sqrt{ rac{m}{2n}}. If k=oâ€‹(m)ğ‘˜ğ‘œğ‘šk=o(\sqrt{m}), there is an nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-QRAC with SR and Îµâ‰¥(1âˆ’onâ€‹(1))â€‹Stabqâ¡[f]ğœ€1subscriptğ‘œğ‘›1subscriptStabğ‘ğ‘“\varepsilon\geq(1-o_{n}(1))\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[f] with qâ‰¥8â€‹m3â€‹Ï€â€‹nğ‘8ğ‘š3ğœ‹ğ‘›q\geq\sqrt{ rac{8m}{3\pi n}}. If k=oâ€‹(m)ğ‘˜ğ‘œğ‘šk=o(\sqrt{m}), there is an nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-EARAC with Îµâ‰¥(1âˆ’onâ€‹(1))â€‹Stabqâ¡[f]ğœ€1subscriptğ‘œğ‘›1subscriptStabğ‘ğ‘“\varepsilon\geq(1-o_{n}(1))\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[f] and q=mnğ‘ğ‘šğ‘›q=\sqrt{ rac{m}{n}}. For any nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}, there is an nâ€‹â†¦1â€‹1ğ‘›1maps-to1n\overset{1}{\mapsto}1 fğ‘“f-PRRAC. Results (a), (b), (c) and (d) use an encoding scheme reminiscent of the concatenation idea from 9   (and suggested to us by Ronald de Wolf). The underlying idea is to randomly break the initial string xâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{-1,1\}^{n} into different â€˜blocksâ€™ and encode them via a standard RAC/QRAC/EARAC. Result (a) breaks xğ‘¥x into â„“â„“\ell blocks and employs the n/â„“â†¦m/â„“maps-toğ‘›â„“ğ‘šâ„“n/\ell\mapsto m/\ell RAC from TheoremÂ 2 on every block, each with n/â„“ğ‘›â„“n/\ell elements, while in results (b)/(c)/(d) we employ the n/mâ†¦1maps-toğ‘›ğ‘š1n/m\mapsto 1 RAC/QRAC/EARAC from TheoremsÂ 1/3/5 in order to encode mğ‘šm blocks, each with n/mğ‘›ğ‘šn/m elements, into a single (qu)bit each, resulting in mğ‘šm encoded (qu)bits. With high probability all the bits from the needed string xSâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}ksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘†superscript11ğ‘˜x_{S}\in\{-1,1\}^{k} will be encoded into different blocks and therefore can be decoded and fğ‘“f evaluated. The decoded string yâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}kğ‘¦superscript11ğ‘˜y\in\{-1,1\}^{k} can be viewed as a â€˜noisyâ€™ xSsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘†x_{S}, to which the noise stability framework can be applied. The bias of the base RAC/QRAC/EARAC thus becomes the parameter qğ‘q in the noise stability of the corresponding fğ‘“f-random access code. As a quick remark, since we opted to lower-bound the parameters qğ‘q in TheoremÂ 12, in resultÂ (b) qğ‘q does not exactly equal the bias from TheoremÂ 1. One could write, though, qâ‰ˆ2â€‹mÏ€â€‹nğ‘2ğ‘šğœ‹ğ‘›q\approx\sqrt{ rac{2m}{\pi n}}. Result (a) is our strongest bound, since it also applies to all other fğ‘“f-random access codes. Moreover, there is some freedom in setting the number of blocks â„“â„“\ell, since the number of encoded bits in TheoremÂ 2 is not fixed to a single number (as opposed to TheoremsÂ 1,Â 3 andÂ 5). The result is a trade-off between the number of bits kğ‘˜k of the Boolean function and the number of encoded bits mğ‘šm. However, the number of encoded bits in result (a) is limited to m=Î©â€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘šÎ©ğ‘›m=\Omega(\log{n}), a characteristic inherited from the RAC in TheoremÂ 2. It is possible to go below this limit by using SR, as demonstrated by results (b), (c) and (d). The above results show that quantum resources offer a modest advantage over the classical fğ‘“f-random access code. On the other hand, result (e) demonstrates that stronger-than-quantum resources like Popescu-Rohrlich boxes can lead to extremely powerful fğ‘“f-random access codes. This is a consequence of violating Information CausalityÂ 9, since one bit transfer allows the access to any bit in a database via Popescu-Rohrlich boxes. From xâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{-1,1\}^{n} a long bit-string xfâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}tsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘“superscript11ğ‘¡x_{f}\in\{-1,1\}^{t}, where t=|ğ’®nk|ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘˜t=|\mathcal{S}_{n}^{k}|, can be constructed with the values fâ€‹(xS)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘†f(x_{S}) for all Sâˆˆğ’®nkğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘˜S\in\mathcal{S}_{n}^{k}. All bits from xfsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘“x_{f} are readable with the aid of Popescu-Rohrlich boxes, with non-signaling constraining the readout to just one bit. The protocol for fğ‘“f-PRRACs is taken fromÂ 9 and uses a pyramid of Popescu-Rohrlich boxes and nests a van Damâ€™s protocolÂ . In SectionÂ 4 we prove an upper bound on the bias of any fğ‘“f-QRAC with SR (and fğ‘“f-RAC) using the same method of the hypercontractive inequality for matrix-valued functions fromÂ . Let f:{âˆ’1,1}kâ†’{âˆ’1,1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript11ğ‘˜11f:\{-1,1\}^{k}	o\{-1,1\} be a Boolean function. For any nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-QRAC with SR and k=oâ€‹(n)ğ‘˜ğ‘œğ‘›k=o(n) the following holds: for any Î·>2â€‹lnâ¡2ğœ‚22\eta>2\ln{2} there is a constant CÎ·subscriptğ¶ğœ‚C_{\eta} such that where L1,â„“â€‹(f)=âˆ‘TâŠ†[k]|T|=â„“|f^â€‹(T)|subscriptğ¿1â„“ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘˜ğ‘‡â„“^ğ‘“ğ‘‡L_{1,\ell}(f)=\sum_{ egin{subarray}{c}T\subseteq[k]\

Indeed, for Parity on kğ‘˜k bits, L1,â„“â€‹(XORk)=1subscriptğ¿1â„“subscriptXORğ‘˜1L_{1,\ell}(\operatorname{XOR}_{k})=1 iff â„“=kâ„“ğ‘˜\ell=k, and so Eq.Â (1) is recovered. The following corollary from TheoremÂ 13 helps to compare the bias upper bound to the bias lower bounds from TheoremÂ 12. Let f:{âˆ’1,1}kâ†’{âˆ’1,1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript11ğ‘˜11f:\{-1,1\}^{k}	o\{-1,1\} be a Boolean function. For any nâ€‹â†¦ğœ€â€‹mğ‘›ğœ€maps-toğ‘šn\overset{\varepsilon}{\mapsto}m fğ‘“f-QRAC with SR and k=oâ€‹(n)ğ‘˜ğ‘œğ‘›k=o(n) the following holds: for any Î·>2â€‹lnâ¡2ğœ‚22\eta>2\ln{2} there is a constant CÎ·subscriptğ¶ğœ‚C_{\eta} such that where degâ¡(f)=maxâ¡{|S|:f^â€‹(S)â‰ 0}degğ‘“:ğ‘†^ğ‘“ğ‘†0\operatorname{deg}(f)=\max\{|S|:\widehat{f}(S)
eq 0\} is the degree of fğ‘“f and q=Î·â€‹mnğ‘ğœ‚ğ‘šğ‘›q=\sqrt{ rac{\eta m}{n}}. Taking degâ¡(f)degğ‘“\operatorname{deg}(f) to be upper-bounded by a constant (for example, if k=Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘˜ğ‘‚1k=O(1)), our bias upper bound matches our bias lower bounds for fğ‘“f-RAC/QRAC with SR up to a global multiplicative constant and a multiplicative constant Î·ğœ‚\sqrt{\eta} in the parameterÂ qğ‘q. We conjecture that the parameter qğ‘q can be improved to mnğ‘šğ‘›\sqrt{ rac{m}{n}}, which might require a stronger version of the hypercontractive inequality.
Other corollaries from TheoremÂ 13 are derived in SectionÂ 4 and compared to our bias lower bounds. Upper boundÂ (2) does not apply to fğ‘“f-EARACs. Previously, it was known that for the special case of standard EARACs (m=1ğ‘š1m=1), the bias Îµğœ€\varepsilon is upper-bounded by 1/n1ğ‘›1/\sqrt{n} (TheoremÂ 5). This upper bound can generalised to EARACs with m>1ğ‘š1m>1 assuming an independence condition (SectionÂ 3.4). The resulting bound is Îµâ‰¤m/nğœ€ğ‘šğ‘›\varepsilon\leq\sqrt{m/n}. We view this as evidence that the bias lower bound for the general case of fğ‘“f-EARACs given in TheoremÂ 12 should actually be tight. Regarding the quantity Stabqâ¡[f]subscriptStabğ‘ğ‘“\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[f] itself, it can be nicely related to the Fourier coefficients of fğ‘“f (see TheoremÂ 17 in the next section). We briefly mention the noise stability for a few functions. For Parity (XORksubscriptXORğ‘˜\operatorname{XOR}_{k}), Stabqâ¡[XORk]=qksubscriptStabğ‘subscriptXORğ‘˜superscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[\operatorname{XOR}_{k}]=q^{k}, and, more generally, for any function Ï‡Sâ€‹(x)=âˆiâˆˆSxisubscriptğœ’ğ‘†ğ‘¥subscriptproductğ‘–ğ‘†subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\chi_{S}(x)=\prod_{i\in S}x_{i}, Stabqâ¡[Ï‡S]=q|S|subscriptStabğ‘subscriptğœ’ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ‘†\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[\chi_{S}]=q^{|S|}. As for the Majority function (MAJksubscriptMAJğ‘˜\operatorname{MAJ}_{k}), one can show thatÂ [46, TheoremÂ 5.18] 2Ï€â€‹arcsinâ¡qâ‰¤Stabqâ¡[MAJk]â‰¤2Ï€â€‹arcsinâ¡q+Oâ€‹(11âˆ’q2â€‹k)2ğœ‹ğ‘subscriptStabğ‘subscriptMAJğ‘˜2ğœ‹ğ‘ğ‘‚11superscriptğ‘2ğ‘˜ rac{2}{\pi}\arcsin{q}\leq\operatorname{Stab}_{q}[\operatorname{MAJ}_{k}]\leq rac{2}{\pi}\arcsin{q}+O\left( rac{1}{\sqrt{1-q^{2}}\sqrt{k}}ight). Other examples can be found inÂ 1. Moreover, a randomized algorithm for approximating the noise stability of monotone Boolean functions up to relative error was proposed inÂ . In SectionÂ 3 we present protocols for all our fğ‘“f-random access codes, and in SectionÂ 4 we derive an upper bound on the bias of fğ‘“f-QRACs with SR.
